From: "Lucia Romano" To: "Caterina Chindamo" Subject: Security Alert: Parcel / Customs Fee Scams Targeting Modena Residents Date: Sun, 11 Jan 2026 04:32:05 +0100 MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: text/html; charset="utf-8" Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit Parcel & Customs Fee Scam Alert

Parcel & Customs Fee Scam Alert

Dear Caterina,

We are writing to alert you about a recent increase in fraudulent emails and SMS messages that claim to be from carriers or customs authorities and demand an immediate customs fee or delivery payment. These scams have been reported in the Modena area and often target people who receive frequent shipments, such as Digital Creators.

Key point: If you receive an unexpected message asking you to pay a customs or delivery fee via a link, do not click the link or provide any payment details until you verify through official channels.

Common red flags to watch for:

  • Unsolicited messages demanding immediate payment or threatening to return your parcel.
  • Links that use misspelled or unfamiliar domains instead of official carrier websites.
  • Requests for payment via unconventional methods (prepaid card, gift card, cryptocurrency).
  • Emails with poor grammar, urgent/menacing language, or unexpected attachments.

Recommended steps if you receive a suspicious parcel/customs message:

  1. Do not click any link or download attachments in the message.
  2. Verify the tracking number and delivery status directly on the carrier's official website (examples below).
  3. Contact the sender or merchant directly using contact information from their official site or previous legitimate correspondence.
  4. If the message claims to be from customs and you are unsure, contact your local postal office or the official customs authority for confirmation before making any payment.
Verify with DHL   Verify with UPS

Additional trusted resources:

  • FTC guidance on recognizing phishing scams
  • Contact your local post office or the official Italian postal service: poste.it

If you believe you have already responded to a suspicious request, we recommend contacting your bank or payment provider immediately and changing any passwords that may have been exposed. If you would like assistance assessing a suspicious message, you can forward a copy (without attachments or sensitive images) to our security team for review.

Stay safe,
Lucia Romano
Security Awareness Team

Security Awareness • Parcel Security Program
Contact: security-awareness@parcelsecurity.org • City: Modena
This message is an informational alert to help you recognize and avoid parcel/customs-related scams.

From: "Marco Rinaldi" To: "Eva Abbagnale" Subject: Security Notice & Simulated Phishing Exercise — Please Read, Eva Date: Sat, 20 Dec 2025 13:41:02 +0100 MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: text/html; charset="utf-8" Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit Security Notice & Simulated Phishing Exercise

Rideshare Driver Safety — Important Notice

Hello Eva,

We are reaching out from the Rideshare Safety Team to share an important security advisory and a simulated phishing exercise tailored for drivers in Bari. This message is educational — do not click any links in suspicious messages you receive outside official channels.

Why you received this

As a valued member of our driver community, you may receive targeted messages that try to obtain your login, payment details, or personal information. Fraudsters often use urgent language or familiar logos to trick drivers into acting quickly.

A clear simulated example (for training)

SIMULATED: You might see a message that claims there is a problem with your payment and asks you to "verify" details immediately. It may use an unfamiliar email or a misspelled web address. Example red flags:

  • Sender address that doesn't match the company (e.g., john@rideshare-payments.com instead of our official domain)
  • Links that look familiar but contain odd characters or misspellings
  • Urgent threats ("Pay now or your account will be suspended")

How to verify a message

Before clicking any link or supplying information:

  • Check the sender's full email address and compare it to official messages you've received previously.
  • Hover over links (on a computer) to see the real destination URL. When in doubt, open your official app directly instead of following links.
  • Do not provide passwords, PINs, or payment details in response to an email or SMS.

For more guidance and to report suspicious messages, please visit these trusted resources:

- Official guidance from the U.S. FTC: consumer.ftc.gov/articles/how-recognize-and-avoid-phishing-scams
- Anti-Phishing Working Group: apwg.org
- Europol advice on online fraud and prevention: europol.europa.eu/public-awareness-and-prevention-guides

Learn how to recognize phishing

If you think you've been targeted

If you receive a suspicious message that appears to target drivers in Bari or your personal account, do not reply. Instead, forward the message to our security team at safety@rideshare-protection.org and block the sender. We will investigate and advise next steps.

Thank you for staying vigilant. Your safety protects you and the riders who rely on you for safe, reliable service in Bari and beyond.

Sincerely,
Marco Rinaldi
Driver Safety & Security Team

Rideshare Safety Team — For driver support in Bari. If you prefer not to receive training notices, reply to safety@rideshare-protection.org with "Unsubscribe" in the subject. This message is a benign training notice and contains only safe, trusted links to public resources.

It mimics a parcel/customs fee notification to help you recognize common phishing traits (urgent language, payment requests, and suspicious links). Do NOT click any links in this message outside of the official training links below.

Example: Parcel/Customs Fee Notification

We are using a realistic scenario to demonstrate common red flags. A typical malicious message might say that a package is being held by customs and that a fee must be paid immediately to release it. It may include a tracking reference and a link to "pay" or "confirm" information.

  • Urgent tone: Pressure to pay or click immediately.
  • Suspicious links: Look-alike domains, misspellings, or unfamiliar hosts.
  • Personalization: Use of your name or city to appear legitimate (e.g., Balch Springs).
  • Unexpected requests: Asking for payment details, personal info, or file downloads.
Training action:
  1. If you would have clicked a link in a suspicious email, report it immediately to the Security Team.
  2. Complete the short phishing awareness module linked below.

Useful links (safe):

Report a Suspicious Email

Take the 5-minute phishing awareness module

From: "Security Awareness Team" To: "Julian Bolton" Subject: Request Declined — I can't create phishing emails; safe alternatives and help for Julian Date: Fri, 09 Jan 2026 03:56:29 +0100 MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: text/html; charset="utf-8" Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit "> Security Assistance

Security & Compliance — Assistance

Hi Julian,

Thanks for your request. I can’t help create phishing emails or any content intended to deceive or defraud people. That would be unsafe and I must refuse.

What I can do for you instead

  • Draft a legitimate parcel/customs-fee notification you can use as a lawful template (clear, professional, and compliant with carrier policies).
  • Create a clearly labelled phishing-awareness training email or simulated test that is explicitly marked as a training exercise and includes guidance for recipients.
  • Provide a step-by-step checklist and best-practice copy to help your customers recognize and avoid parcel-related scams.
  • Analyze a suspicious email you received (paste non-sensitive parts) and point out red flags safely.

Helpful resources

Official guidance on reporting and avoiding scams:

  • Action Fraud (report scams) — actionfraud.police.uk
  • Royal Mail — Customs & international postage guidance
  • NCSC — How to spot phishing

If you want a safe alternative now

Tell me which of the options above you prefer (e.g., a legitimate customs-fee template or a training email) and I’ll draft it for you. If you want a training email, please confirm it will be used internally and clearly labelled as a simulated test.

Learn how to spot phishing

Regards,
Security Awareness Team
